d16afa0ae7c.shortDescription: Mining the tech world for lively, meaningful tales.

9ea2299c7f69.description: The machine is stuttering and the engineers are in panic. They are wondering if perhaps they do not understand it as well as they imagined. They are wondering whether they are controlling it at all or whether, perhaps, it is controlling them.— The Dark Mountain Manifesto

header.title: Light on a Dark Mountain
header.description: The machine is stuttering and the engineers are in panic. They are wondering if perhaps they do not understand it as well as they imagined. They are wondering whether they are controlling it at all or whether, perhaps, it is controlling them.— The Dark Mountain Manifesto

9ea2299c7f69.name: Light on a Dark Mountain
9ea2299c7f69.shortDescription: The machine is stuttering and the engineers are in panic.

paragraphs.text: “People are forgetting the value and importance of the display,” he says “Some of the greatest innovations on iPhone over the last ten years have been in display. Displays are not going to go away. We still like to take pictures and we need to look at them, and a disembodied voice is not going to show me what the picture is.”
paragraphs.name: e470

paragraphs.text: Indeed, says Schiller, the success of the iPhone—propelled by the few apps included on the first model, like Mail and Safari and YouTube—led to the open-or-closed issue becoming a non-debate. Inside Apple the answer was suddenly clear: of course it would be open. (And the security fears that Jobs cited to me on day one mysteriously vanished.) All those critics, including me, who kept urging Apple to make the iPhone open were irrelevant. Not long after launch, Apple began implementing a system that opened the iPhone to a wide range of creators who would make countless apps. Apps that would amplify the iPhone’s impact.

We met at the Cupertino campus that will soon be supplanted as Apple’s executive quarters by an exotic new circular headquarters building a few miles away. As is very common when people sit together these days, on the table were our iPhones, sitting face down like the ubiquitous pistols that gunslingers rest on the bar in old Westerns. Their presence was a reminder that at business meetings, restaurants, living room couches, and dinner tables, you see smart phones on table surfaces or under them, all too often with someone’s eyes cast downwards on a message, an email, a Facebook story, or even a game.
paragraphs.name: a12d

paragraphs.text: I wondered how the success of the iPhone changed Apple itself. Schiller preferred to view the iPhone’s as part of a continuum of change that had already begun with Jobs’s return, and the creation of the iPod.
paragraphs.name: 13d9

paragraphs.text: We met at the Cupertino campus that will soon be supplanted as Apple’s executive quarters by an exotic new circular headquarters building a few miles away. As is very common when people sit together these days, on the table were our iPhones, sitting face down like the ubiquitous pistols that gunslingers rest on the bar in old Westerns. Their presence was a reminder that at business meetings, restaurants, living room couches, and dinner tables, you see smart phones on table surfaces or under them, all too often with someone’s eyes cast downwards on a message, an email, a Facebook story, or even a game.
paragraphs.name: a12d

paragraphs.text: “I actually think the leaps in the later versions are as big and sometimes even bigger now,” he says. “I think our expectations are changing more, not the leaps in the products. If you look through every version—from the original iPhone to the iPhone 3G to the 4 to the 4S, you see great changes all throughout. You see screen size change from three and a half inch to four inch to four point seven and five point five. You see cameras going through incredible change, from the first camera that couldn’t shoot video, to then having both a front and a backside camera, to now three cameras with the stuff we’re doing, and with live photos and 4K video.” (Maybe it’s just a happenstance that he didn’t provide examples from iPhone versions 6 and 7.)
paragraphs.name: a931
a12d

954d9e058deb.title: “Apple has lost control of the narrative.”

paragraphs.text: “Apple has lost control of the narrative.” I don’t know. Reviews of its recent releases are overwhelmingly positive. Their adverts are quirky, endearing, and upbeat. High-end product placement in visual media keeps the Apple logo in the public eye and mind. Customer satisfaction is stellar, insuring loyalty repurchasing, and the brand is aspirational…
paragraphs.name: 59c9

paragraphs.name: d1f7

paragraphs.text: What most are dismissing is Apple working on a disruptive laptop, probably as we speak. I’m a musician. We see patterns before others often. The derided MC Pro is like the appetizer. The main dish is coming.

paragraphs.text: Not really. The App Store was and still is the only official way to install anything. And that store is famous for its many, often unclear rules. Apple never made iOS as open as the Mac.
paragraphs.name: 80fc

7bdc1a0d8ff2.title: If the “disembodied voice” can be more intelligent and can show those images up on any device, on…

paragraphs.text: If the “disembodied voice” can be more intelligent and can show those images up on any device, on any display, surely that’s a greater end to aim for that one tied to a device and particular ecosystem? Alexa seems hugely promising. Of course we still want screens; we still want to take pictures and more, but, i’m not going to ask Siri or Alexa to…
paragraphs.name: 3e74

bc26f5ccd421.title: No one should underestimate what Apple did.

paragraphs.text: No one should underestimate what Apple did. But I do wish Apple would stop their pretense that they performed magic with the introduction of the iPhone (or the Mac before it, come to that).
paragraphs.name: 5e87

12a409bbb9ac.title: Mr. Schiller’s dismissive statements around ubiquitous voice concern me.

paragraphs.text: Mr. Schiller’s dismissive statements around ubiquitous voice concern me. The appeal of an Echo is that it’s becoming a part of the family experience. That it’s NOT just mine.
paragraphs.name: ee7e

paragraphs.text: Also, the Echo is not about replacing screens or being stuck to the kitchen. It’s about ubiquity. And of course we’ll always need and want screens. It…

c580823ea627.title: Bravo. I think I just broke the Highlighter.

paragraphs.text: Bravo. I think I just broke the Highlighter.

50 years? Seriously? The only similarity between today’s systems and the 1960’s are QUERTY keyboards and electricity. I doubt we’ll be using rectangular external communication devices in 2068…by then this stuff will all be implants.
paragraphs.name: 524a

paragraphs.text: Or it won’t exist because we’ll all be living in a version of “The Road”, but that’s another post LOL

ec184b51e4c9.title: If AirPods are a successful innovation like the iPhone & iPod and the Walkman & microwave & PC and…

paragraphs.text: If AirPods are a successful innovation like the iPhone & iPod and the Walkman & microwave & PC and not just an interesting gimmick like an N64 disk drive, or Google Glass, or XBox Kinect then it could signal an interesting new phase analogous to, at the least, the introduction of the Walkman and at the greatest, as impactful as the TV.
paragraphs.name: 6db6

db0ce66d0437.title: While I have the greatest respect for Mr.

paragraphs.text: While I have the greatest respect for Mr. Levy as a writer, the only word that comes to mind when I read this article is “fawning”. It’d be nice if there were a little more journalistic detachment here and less use of phrases like “redefine the category” and “mind-boggling”.
paragraphs.name: c248

75d8cb185962.title: Note: In the original I implied that Phil didn’t include iPhone 6 and 7 in his explanation of how…

paragraphs.text: Note: In the original I implied that Phil didn’t include iPhone 6 and 7 in his explanation of how innovation continued. Actually, he did mention some of the new features in those, like the improved camera and screen size. So I took out the observation, as it was wrong.
paragraphs.name: e327

582b8f04b5ca.title: This is such a good metaphor.

paragraphs.text: This is such a good metaphor. But oddly, while the pistol increased visceral awareness of the person sitting across from you, the smartphone is an exit door from situational awareness. Perhaps things are different in open-carry states where you can put down both side-by-side?
paragraphs.name: ab21

1c05c421b3ca.title: Platforms are revolutionary — products are evolutionary.

paragraphs.text: Platforms are revolutionary — products are evolutionary.

The iPhone is the most successful technology platform in history. It has succeeded in becoming the defacto mass market smartphone brand for this very reason. The value of the iPhone is bolstered by massively vertical + horizontal integration of the Apple ecosystem (*)…

paragraphs.text: The iPhone was revolutionary. I had the first one, I have an iPhone 7 now. But Apple is not innovating as they used to do. And this show in a loss of pricing power. As I further expand on in this blog post: http://blog.pricebeam.com/apple-and-pricing-power
paragraphs.name: b145
